Bos Bukalapak Ungkap Pelajaran Berharga dari Bisnis Mie Ayam
02 Nov 2019, 10:44 by Pribadi Wicaksono (Kontributor), Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Yogyakarta - Jauh sebelum sukses dengan platform e-commerce Bukalapak, tiga serangkai Muhammad Fajrin Rasyid, Achmad Zaky dan Nugroho Herucahyono punya cerita tak terlupakan tentang gerobak mie ayam. Mereka bertiga pernah memiliki usaha mie ayam gerobak semasa kuliah di Institut Teknologi Bandung (ITB).
MuhammadFajrinRasyid yang kini menjabat sebagai Co-Founder dan PresidentBukalapak menceritakan usaha mie ayam gerobak itu dijalankan bersama 20 orang rekan kampusnya dengan mengambil tempat jualan di halaman asrama kampus mereka.
"Alhamdullilah, bisnis mie ayam itu berjalan satu bulan saja," ujar Fajrin saat berbicara di acara Jogja Startup Day 2019 di Universitas Amikom Yogyakarta, Sabtu, 2 November 2019. Sampai akhirnya bisnis sambilan itu pun dengan cepat gulung tikar.
Fajrin menganalisa, saat itu ia dan rekan rekannya rupanya saling menggantungkan diri satu sama lain. Sehingga tidak terlalu memikirkan tanggung jawab masing masing atas usaha bersama itu.
Sebagai contoh, salah satu rekan membolos berjaga di lapak stardengan berbagai macam alasan, seperti praktikum di kampus atau yang lainnya. Lalu orang itu menyerahkan pada 19 orang pengelola sisanya. Padahal 19 orang yang dipasrahi mengurus ternyata juga berpikiran serupa, menggantungkan kepada lainnya.
Bahkan pernah saat sedang waktunya jam makan dan ramai ramainya orang jajan, warung mie ayam itu tidak ada yang menjaga sama sekali. Semua pengelolanya sudah sibuk sendiri sendiri dengan urusannya.
"Dari tutupnya usaha itu kami belajar bahwa kalau punya bisnis, pertama yang harus dipunyai rule of responsibility yang jelas," ujar pria yang melanjutkan kuliahnya di Harvard dan Standford University di Amerika Serikat itu. Pelajaran tentang pembagian tanggung jawab itu akhirnya mulai diterapkan saat Fajrin dan dua rekan kampusnya Achmad Zaky dan Nugroho Herucahyono merintis Bukalapak.
Kerja keras tim akhirnya membuat Bukalapak, yang kini tercatat sebagai startup unicorn Indonesia ini meraup gross merchandise value (GMV) atau total penjualan dan volume transaksi pada semester I 2019 senilai US$ 5 miliar atau setara Rp 71,2 triliun.
CEO Bukalapak Achmad Zaky dalam keterangan tertulisnya di awal Agustus 2019 lalu menyampaikan ada lebih dari dua juta transaksi dalam sehari di platform Bukalapak. Adapun laba bruto per bulan tercatat dua kali lipat lebih tinggi dibandingkan angka Desember 2018.
"Angka tersebut mungkin terlihat bagi banyak orang sebagai musim panen yang membawa hasil jerih payah merawat saat musim silih berganti," tulis Zaky dalam rilisnya seperti dikutip dari Antara.
Selama sembilan tahun operasional, perusahaan e-commerce ini mampu menciptakan dua juta unit warung digital dan agen wirausaha mandiri Mitra Bukalapak di 477 kota maupun kabupaten di Indonesia. Zaky mengklaim, jumlah rata-rata pelanggan Warung Mitra dua kali lebih banyak ketimbang pengunjung toko di pusat perbelanjaan.

Bos Bukalapak Reveals Valuable Lessons from the Chicken Noodle Business
02 Nov 2019, 10:44 by Pribadi Wicaksono (Contributor), Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Yogyakarta - Long before the success of the Bukalapak e-commerce platform, the triad of Muhammad Fajrin Rasyid, Achmad Zaky and Nugroho Herucahyono had unforgettable stories about chicken noodle carts. The three of them had owned a chicken cart noodle business while studying at the Bandung Institute of Technology (ITB).
Muhammad Fajrin Rasyid who now serves as Co-Founder and President of Bukalapak told about the chicken noodle cart business that was run with 20 of his campus partners by taking up selling points in their campus dormitory yard.
"Thank God, the chicken noodle business has been running for only one month," Fajrin said while speaking at the Jogja Startup Day 2019 at Amikom University in Yogyakarta, Saturday, November 2, 2019. Until finally the odd business was quickly closed.
Fajrin analyzed, at that time he and his colleagues seemed to depend on each other. So as not to think too much about the responsibilities of each of those joint ventures.
For example, one of the classmates who ditched in a stall stall with a variety of reasons, such as practicum on campus or the other. Then the person handed over to the remaining 19 managers. Even though the 19 people who were treated as caregivers turned out to be thinking the same, hanging on to others.
Even when it was time to eat and there were lots of snacks, the chicken noodle stall had no guard at all. All the managers are busy themselves with their own affairs.
"From the closing of the business we learned that if you have a business, first you must have a clear rule of responsibility," said the man who continued his studies at Harvard and Stanford University in the United States. The lesson about the division of responsibilities finally began to be applied when Fajrin and two of his campus colleagues Achmad Zaky and Nugroho Herucahyono pioneered Bukalapak.
The team's hard work finally made Bukalapak, now listed as an Indonesian unicorn startup, reap gross merchandise value (GMV) or total sales and transaction volume in the first semester of 2019 valued at US $ 5 billion or equivalent to Rp 71.2 trillion.
Bukalapak CEO Achmad Zaky said in his written statement in early August 2019 that there were more than two million transactions a day on the Bukalapak platform. The gross profit per month is double that of December 2018.
"This figure may be seen to many as the harvest season which brings the results of caring for the time when the seasons change," Zaky wrote in his release as quoted by Antara.
During its nine years of operation, the e-commerce company was able to create two million units of digital stalls and independent entrepreneurial agents Mitra Bukalapak in 477 cities and districts in Indonesia. Zaky claims, the average number of Warung Mitra customers is twice as many as store visitors in a shopping center.
